docs.snippet: Unlike football and basketball, sports that do not generate revenue and which often embody the spirit of amateurism in college sports are being cut....
docs.lead_paragraph: Unlike football and basketball, sports that do not generate revenue and which often embody the spirit of amateurism in college sports are being cut.
docs.abstract: Julie Macur Sports Of The Times column laments Temple University's decision to cut its men's and women's crew teams, along with five other varsity sports; notes that move affects more than 200 student-athletes and will save university $3 million to $3.5 million a year.

headline.main: At Temple, Spirit of Amateurism Is Abandoned by a River
headline.print_headline: At Temple, Spirit of Amateurism Is Abandoned by a River

docs.snippet: After much contentious debate, construction on a 3.6 mile streetcar line in Cincinnati is moving ahead, with financial support from a foundation....
docs.lead_paragraph: After much contentious debate, construction on a 3.6 mile streetcar line in Cincinnati is moving ahead, with financial support from a foundation.
docs.abstract: Construction on 3.6-mile streetcar line in Cincinnati is moving ahead with financial support from the Haile US Bank Foundation; critics call project a debt trap that will sink the city but supporters say proposed new streetcar line is an ambitious development effort that is central to city's revival.

headline.main: Cincinnati Streetcar Plan Pits Desire for Growth Against Fiscal Restraint
headline.print_headline: Cincinnati Streetcar Plan Pits Desire for Growth Against Fiscal Restraint

keywords.value: Haile, Carol Ann and Ralph V Jr, US Bank Foundation
keywords.name: organizations

docs.snippet: Brad Grey of Paramount Pictures has chosen to produce fewer films, giving up revenue, but increasing profitability as the industry moves into survival mode....
docs.lead_paragraph: Brad Grey of Paramount Pictures has chosen to produce fewer films, giving up revenue, but increasing profitability as the industry moves into survival mode.
docs.abstract: Paramount Pictures ranks last among major studios in annual box-office race, with under $900 million to date in domestic ticket sales, down 50 percent from 2001 peak; chief executive Brad Grey is choosing to produce fewer films, giving up revenue, but increasing profitability as the industry moves into survival mode.

headline.main: Strong Profit Margin at Paramount Pictures Underlines a Hollywood Shift

byline.original: By MICHAEL CIEPLY and BROOKS BARNES
